awd_titl_txt: Radiation Tools for the Determination of Temperatures and Concentrations from Radiometric Measurements in Laminar and Turbulent Combustion Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
0966627
Modest

This research involves the prediction and measurement of species and/or soot concentrations and temperatures in laminar as well as turbulent combustion systems. Although optical diagnostics have reached high levels of refinement, it remains very difficult to make accurate measurements in turbulent combustion environments. The difficulties are largely attributable to the highly non-linear interactions between the structure of the turbulent flow field and the corresponding radiation field. Not only do these interactions make measurements difficult, they also have an important effect on both the heat release and the chemical cascading as well as soot formation that is inherent in combustion systems. This proposal seeks to explain, using fundamental experimental, analytical and computational approaches, the nature of the turbulence-radiation interaction. 


Intellectual Merit: Nonintrusive spectral radiation tools will be developed to measure species concentrations and temperatures in both laminar and turbulent reacting flows, based primarily on line-of-sight techniques. The measurements will be used to reconstruct the distributions of the variables of interest, and guide the development of, and validate theoretical models for such flows. One unique aspect of the research is inclusion of the predicted response of instrumentation that would be used to measure the quantities of interest in a companion experiment. This capability reduces the uncertainties in comparisons made between measurements and predictions, and increases our understanding of the underlying physical phenomena. The predictive model is based upon the transported PDF method.

Broader Impacts: Turbulent combustion is associated with production and/or conversion of most of the energy used in the U.S. The associated heat transfer, including the radiation heat transfer, is utilized in applications ranging from electric power generation to transportation. Graduate and undergraduate students will be engaged in the research at the PIs institution, which is a new component of the University of California System. Undergraduate students will be primarily responsible for making the experimental measurements, giving students from underrepresented groups important exposure to advanced research. Collaboration will be made with researchers at Edwards Air Force Base and Sandia National Laboratories.

por.por_cntn:
Advanced optical diagnostics and multi-scale simulation tools will play central roles in the development of next-generation clean and efficient combustion systems. Accurate measurements of temperature and combustion gas concentrations are critical for monitoring and controlling the combustion systems, making them safer and more efficient. There are presently several ways to measure these quantities, but it remains very difficult to accurately measure temperature and concentrations in a combustion system without disturbing the flow field. In this research, temperatures and gas concentrations are retrieved based on the fact that combustion gases emit and absorb infrared light, and do so quite differently at different temperatures and gas concentrations.

 The objective of the current research was to develop nonintrusive tools that allow to measure temperature and combustion gas concentrations. These tools were developed for laminar combustion systems and, in particular, turbulent combustion systems where the nonlinear effects from the turbulence can be significant. An updated absorption coefficient database was created first based on the latest spectroscopic database HITEMP 2010, which enables efficient prediction of the spectral emission and/or absorption from combustion gases, such as carbon dioxide, carbon monoxide and water vapor. Temperature and gas concentration calculation models were then developed, which are able to retrieve temperature and gas concentrations for homogeneous laminar gaseous media, for nonhomogeneous laminar gaseous media and, finally, mean temperatures, concentrations and their turbulence moments in turbulent combustion gases.

 The first model was developed to retrieve temperature and gas concentrations for a laminar homogeneous system. This model was validated against experimental measurements of transmissivity spectra for carbon dioxide and water vapor for a wide range of temperatures and species concentrations.

 The second analytical model was geared toward nonhomogeneous gaseous media. It was found that transmissivities of combustion gases are not sensitive to temperature and concentration distributions and, therefore, emission spectra need to be used to retrieve temperature profiles. Several types of temperature profiles were retrieved accurately using this model. It was found that using two-sided measured spectra can significantly improve the results of deducing actual temperature profiles.

To develop the third analytical model for turbulent systems, the nonlinear interaction between turbulence and radiation has to be considered. Such an analytical model for a path along the detector's line-of-sight was developed to deduce time-averaged and root-mean-square values of temperature and concentrations. This model works for single gas species as well as for mixtures of combustion gases, and is capable of retrieving turbulence length scales from the optical measurements, as well.

 In summary, inverse radiation models were developed and these model are able to retrieve temperature and species concentrations for homogeneous laminar gaseous media, temperature profiles and average species concentrations for nonhomogeneous laminar gaseous media, and time-averaged and root-mean-square values as well as turbulent length scales for turbulent gaseous media.
